Many times I’ve been alone, and many times I’ve cried
 Anyway, you’ll never know the many ways I’ve tried
In the Let It Be…Naked version of this song, the lyric is actually changed to “Many times I’ve been alone, and many times I’ve cried. Anyway you’ve always known, the many ways I’ve tried.”

It is ironic that, owing to the melancholic tones in the song, the orchestral arrangement contributed towards the break-up of The Beatles.

McCartney and Spector disagreed over the composition of the song. McCartney preferred the traditional four-man recording and wanted to release the song like that, whilst Spector controversially overdubbed the final recording with an arrangement.

Following the release of the song, McCartney legally pursued the breakup of The Beatles in April 1970.

You left me standing here a long, long time ago
 Don’t leave me waiting here
 Lead me to your door
McCartney may not be blaming Asher for his pondering nostalgia over her, only pleading that the memories of his lost love will no longer haunt him.
And still they lead me back to the long and winding road
McCartney implies that the memories of lost, and former love, will return to him regardless of how long he has waited.

The wild and windy night that the rain washed away
 Has left a pool of tears, crying for the day
 Why leave me standing here?
 Let me know the way

McCartney is voicing his anxiety over his stormy, messy past and is pleading for normality to be restored (‘Why leave me standing here, let me know the way’). Although McCartney was already in a relationship with Linda Eastman at the time, it is normal to express and sometimes ponder sentimentally over our former loved ones!

‘The Long and Winding Road’ is arranged with a repetitive opening theme. Additionally, the melody and subsequent lyrics do not validate whether the song is supposed to start in the opening stanza, as it is unclear where the bridge begins, and the lack of traditional chorus.

Lennon, unusually, plays bass guitar in this song and made several mistakes during the recording of this song. He plays it in a disenchanted, ragged style (which many commentators believe is purposeful).



Harrison playing guitar, and Lennon playing bass during the music video in Let It Be (1970)

I’ve seen that road before
 It always leads me here
 Lead me to your door

McCartney’s inspiration for ‘The Long and Winding Road’ emerged from the growing tensions in the Beatles. The lyrics in the song echo the unpleasant, grueling period of The White Album’s development, McCartney’s failed relationship with Jane Asher, the Let it Be sessions and Epstein’s death, amongst other segments in The Beatles' history.

One way to interpret this is that McCartney expresses his belief that hardships are inevitable (truly prophetic, as the song was recorded in January 1969, eight months before Lennon announced his departure from The Beatles!)

This echoes many of The Beatles early lyrics, such as [“She Loves You”]. These very lyrics echo the legacy of The Beatles' music, setting in stone the controversy of the orchestral arrangement.(http://rock.rapgenius.com/2768581).
